;外国电影制作人和制片人参加了在北京举办的在线活动，旨在教授更多内容超过 10,000 名政府官员、学者、记者和外交官如何让自己的信息对外国受众更具吸引力。

;

;周二的全天网络研讨会由中国国际传播发展中心 (CCICD) 组织，该中心是隶属于中共中央宣传部。这是去年启动的一个项目的一部分，该项目旨在赞助有关中国的纪录片并促进中外制片人之间的合作。

;

;政治局新成员和习近平的亲信确认担任中国宣传部长

;

;演讲者包括奥斯卡奖得主马尔科姆·克拉克在内的三位驻华外国纪录片导演、四位中国纪录片制片人和探索频道的一位高管。

;

;CCICD 社交媒体账户上的活动摘要称，该网络研讨会的目的是解决针对国际受众的信息无效问题，因为它采用与针对国内受众相同的语气，外国人觉得没有说服力。

;

;“对外宣传和对内宣传没有区别，对外宣传没有区别”已经变得像内部宣传了。这是当前国际传播工作的挑战和痛苦。

;

;“中国从来不缺好故事。但为什么这么多讲好中国故事的故事最终却变得陈词滥调或无法传达信息？”

;

;CCICD 成立于 2021 年，旨在出版和推广有关共产党及其关键文件的书籍。

;

;它表示，网上讨论的一个结论是，当关注个体故事或针对特定受众时，讲故事会更有效，而不是试图讲述一个关于中国的宏大故事。

;

;“最重要的一点是外国观众能否在情感上产生共鸣。

;

;活动中还听到了反对抄袭西方叙事或支持对中国的批评的警告。

;

; 2013年，习近平主席敦促媒体“讲好中国故事”，通过精心讲述国家和平崛起的故事，增强国家的“国际话语权”。

;

;中国也愿意投入大量资金花钱传播其信息，例如自 2011 年起在纽约时代广场租用大屏幕来播放其信息。

;

;中国外交政策界中熊猫与狼之间正在酝酿冲突

;

;然而，随着中西方关系日益紧张，以及“战狼”外交（因一系列针对国内观众的高度民族主义动作电影而得名）的兴起，多项调查显示，西方对中国的看法变得越来越负面.

;

;克拉克因讲述一位癌症患者和一位被关押在纳粹集中营的母亲的纪录片而于 1989 年和 2014 年获得奥斯卡奖，他说：“中国一直是西方许多负面宣传的对象过去10年。我想做的是反击这种负面宣传，不是通过讲述中国的快乐和美好故事，而是通过简单地讲述这里发生的事情的真相。”

;

;2018 年，英国人做了一个纪录片《更好的天使》采访了外交官和商人，以及中美两国普通民众之间的互动，他当时表示，这是为了呈现比西方媒体更平衡的国家观点。< /p>;

;另一位演讲者、探索频道全球内容副总裁 Vikram Channa 引用了腾讯与探索频道 2021 年合作项目《勇士之旅》的例子。

;

;该系列节目以生存纪录片的形式展示了一位新西兰探险家和中国名人重现 1930 年代共产党红军长征的情景。

;

;网络研讨会的其他发言者包括驻北京的美国纪录片导演米切尔·法卡斯 (Mitchell Farkas) 和中国纪录片导演张同道。

;

;该网络研讨会是去年启动的名为“影像可能性联合制作计划”的项目的一部分，该项目旨在赞助国际合作并制作有关中国的纪录片。

;

;该项目是联合制作公司-在国务院新闻办公室等政府部门的指导下，由中国国际通信集团、探索频道、福建省广播电视管理局、福建传媒集团、腾讯和视频平台哔哩哔哩主办。

;

;“我们认为这些都不应该是风险，中国李克强在其访问期间多次呼吁加强“开放与合作”，而欧盟内部对中国战略依赖的担忧日益凸显。

;

;在周一与德国高层首席执行官的会议上，李克强警告称，缺乏合作将是“最大的风险”，他承诺在汽车制造、高科技和新能源等领域深化合作。会见肖尔茨。

;

;在对柏林和慕尼黑进行为期四天的访问期间，李克强与巴斯夫、梅赛德斯-奔驰、宝马和大众等德国一些最大的科技巨头签署了合作协议据中国国家发展和改革委员会的声明。

;

;

;中国总理还参观了西门子总部，了解农业和机器人技术以及磁共振成像和商业数字化方面的新技术。

;

;李随后前往巴黎参加周四开始的为期两天的新全球融资协议峰会。预计他将会见几位政府高级官员，包括法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙。

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 22:20:02 +0800 Snakes on a plain: Chinese-led study shows when the serpents shed their legshttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3224929/snakes-plain-chinese-led-study-shows-when-serpents-shed-their-legs?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.22 21:25;
;;

;新研究表明，蛇——那些无数噩梦的令人毛骨悚然的盘绕体——过去常常看起来像有很多不同。

;

;根据同类中最大规模的基因组调查，蛇曾经有腿。

;

;由中国科学院研究人员领导的这项新研究发现，蛇曾经有腿。蛇起源于白垩纪早期（大约 1.18 亿年前），当时恐龙统治着地球。

;

;蛇的祖先是蜥蜴，这是一种爬行动物，在大约 6500 万年前的大规模灭绝事件后迅速多样化一场灾难夺去了地球上四分之三的生命，其中包括恐龙的灭绝。

;

;蛇经历了各种进化变化，包括肢体丧失、身体变长以及肺部和肺部不对称的变化。这项新研究周一发表在同行评审期刊《细胞》上。

;

;作者通过分析 14 个基因组，确定了导致蛇进化变化的基因、调控元件和结构变异。来自12个蛇科，约占所有蛇种的84%。

;

;该研究的通讯作者、中科院成都生物研究所研究员李家堂表示，之前的研究分析了一个特定的蛇种或科，但他的团队希望捕获蛇基因组的更全面的图片。

;

;“此外，我们测量了全基因组数据并获得了更多遗传信息来支持我们的假设。周二，官方媒体《中国科学报》援引李的话说：“以前的研究只测量了蛇类的几个基因片段。”

;

;除极地以外，各大洲都有蛇的踪迹。他们生活在陆地和海洋、森林和沙漠中。蛇有300多个科、4000多种蛇种。

;

;“我们想从基因的角度解释蛇是如何适应这些复杂的环境的。”李说。

;

;该研究项目于2018年正式启动。为了获得新鲜样本，团队每年花费两到三个月的时间在中国西北地区新疆的沙漠或中国北方高原采集样本。

;

;在此过程中，研究人员发现了一些影响蛇进化变化的关键基因。

;

;蠕虫如何帮助科学家了解人类大脑中基因的功能

;

;一个基因——PTCH1——在肢体发育中发挥着重要作用。研究小组还研究了删除该基因如何影响小鼠的肢体发育。

;

;利用 CRISPR-Cas9 基因编辑技术，作者对小鼠进行了编辑，删除了 PTCH1 基因。当它一周大时，研究人员观察到，与正常小鼠相比，该小鼠的体重明显较低，体形也较短。此外，成年 PTCH1 缺失小鼠的指骨明显较短。

;

;“这些结果表明，该基因的缺失会抑制骨骼生长，包括四肢手指的生长，”作者写道。

;

;根据这项研究，四肢的丧失导致蛇的身体蓝图被拉长。作者还确定了解释这些变长身体进化的关键基因。

;

;研究称，变长的身体伴随着肺部等内脏器官的变化。

;

;在现代蛇或蛇类中，左肺要么不存在，要么比右肺小得多。作者发现蛇体内缺乏一种在左右发育平衡中发挥作用的基因。另一种促进肺部发育的基因也在蛇中丢失。

;

;粪甲虫和蝴蝶的魅力，以及昆虫为何重要

;

;作者表示，他们的研究可能会增进对昆虫的理解。李说，他的团队将开展蛇毒研究，为抗蛇毒药物的开发提供科学支持。

;在泰坦尼克号残骸附近寻找失踪潜水器的多国任务仍专注于营救美国海岸警卫队周四坚称，五名船员还活着，尽管担心船上的氧气可能已经耗尽。

;

;周四，随着对泰坦的大规模搜寻行动失败，又部署了两艘无人潜艇。位于北大西洋海面和水下两英里多（近四公里）之间的大片海域，已进入关键阶段。

;

;海岸警卫队官员坚称他们仍然“充满希望”，但面临的挑战找到并救出活着的船员的任务似乎越来越艰巨。

;

;根据潜艇可容纳长达 96 小时紧急空气的能力，救援人员估计乘客可能会在周四凌晨耗尽氧气。

;

;失踪的泰坦尼克号旅游潜水器上有谁？

;

;多国响应组织者（包括美国和加拿大军用飞机、海岸警卫队船只和远程制导机器人）正在将工作重点集中在北方大西洋接近声纳检测到的水下噪音。

;

;一艘配备无人机器人的法国研究船周四抵达沉船附近，该机器人能够在水下最深 6,000 米（近 20,000 英尺）的深度进行搜索。

;

;英国南极调查局的海洋专家 Rob Larter 在新闻发布会上表示，他认为 Victor 6000 机器人是水下救援的“主要希望”。

;

;另一名加拿大人周四早些时候，载有医务人员和减压室的船只正在前往该地区的途中，加拿大媒体报道称，预计该船不会在中午之前抵达。

;

;这些声音让小型游船上的乘客燃起了希望。尽管专家们还无法确认它们的来源，但它们仍然活着。

;

;“坦白说，我们不知道它们是什么，”美国海岸警卫队队长杰米·弗雷德里克说。

;

;“坦白说，我们不知道它们是什么。” >;

;“我们必须保持乐观和希望。”

;

;据美国称，这艘名为“泰坦”的潜水器于周日上午 8:00 开始下降，原定于七小时后重新浮出水面。海岸警卫队。

;

;这艘 21 英尺（6.5 米）长的旅游船在前往观看泰坦尼克号的旅程中不到两个小时就与母船失去了联系，泰坦尼克号距离超过两英里（近四公里）北大西洋海面以下。

;

;泰坦载着英国亿万富翁哈米什·哈丁和巴基斯坦大亨沙赫扎达·达乌德及其儿子苏尔曼，他们也拥有英国公民身份。

;

;OceanGate Expeditions 收费 250,000 美元船上还有该公司的首席执行官斯托克顿·拉什 (Stockton Rush) 和法国潜艇操作员保罗-亨利·纳尔吉奥莱 (Paul-Henri Nargeolet)，他因经常在该地点潜水而被昵称为“泰坦尼克号先生”。

;

; p>;

;船只和飞机已经搜寻了 10,000 平方英里（约 20,000 平方公里）的地表水域，以寻找这艘船，该船试图在距加拿大纽芬兰海岸约 400 英里的地方潜水。

;

;一架加拿大 P-3 飞机检测到噪音，救援人员重新安置了两艘在水下搜索的遥控潜水器 (ROV) 和一艘具有声纳功能的水面舰艇。

;

;ROV 搜索尚未产生结果，但数据来自加拿大飞机已与美国海军专家共享进行声学分析。

;

;“已经收到多份有关噪音的报告，并且正在对每一项噪音进行分析，”伍兹霍尔海洋研究所的卡尔·哈茨菲尔德 (Carl Hartsfield) 说道.

;

;他补充说，这些声音“被描述为撞击声。”

;

;海军已派出专门的绞车系统，用于从极深的地方吊起重物以及其他设备和人员，而五角大楼已经部署了三架 C-130 飞机和三架 C-17。

;

;由于天气恶劣，泰坦号的任务预计将成为今年唯一一次载人前往泰坦尼克号的旅行，哈丁事先在 Instagram 帖子中写道.

;

;1912 年，泰坦尼克号在从英国到纽约的处女航中撞上冰山沉没，船上载有 2,224 名乘客和船员。超过 1,500 人死亡。

;

;它于 1985 年被发现，至今仍吸引着航海专家和水下游客。

;

;随着氧气供应减少，救援人员竞相寻找失踪的泰坦尼克号旅游潜艇

;

; h3>;

;在大气中测得的该深度的压力是海平面压力的 400 倍。

;

;伦敦大学学院海洋工程教授阿利斯泰尔·格雷格 (Alistair Greig) 基于以下情况提出了两种可能的情况：泰坦的图像。

;

;他说，如果它出现电气或通信问题，它可能会浮出水面并保持漂浮状态，“等待被发现”——据报道，该船只能从外部解锁.

;

;“另一种情况是耐压船体受到损害——泄漏，”他在一份声明中说。

;

;“那么预后不好。”

;

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 20:50:01 +0800 Rich young Asians urged to build culture of giving ‘boldly’ to tackle climate change, inequalityhttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3225050/rich-young-asians-urged-build-culture-giving-boldly-tackle-climate-change-inequality?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.22 19:52;
;;

;Asia's super-rich are being urged into philanthropy to help tackle the overlapping crises facing the region, from climate change to poor access to education and healthcare, as mountains of family money are transferred to a younger, more socially conscious generation willing to give.

;

;This week in Kuala Lumpur, 1,300 delegates joined Asia's largest philanthropic gathering, hosted by Singapore-based Asian Venture Philanthropy Network (AVPN) and Yayasan Hasanah, the social impact arm of Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund.

;

;The focus on social impact comes during a golden era of wealth creation across Asia – mirrored by widening inequality which has been exacerbated by the pandemic.

;

;'Extreme weather events': Asia set for supercharged heat as El Nino looms

;

;The number of US-dollar millionaires in Asia is poised to double to nearly 80 million by the end of the decade, according to a 2022 report by HSBC, outstripping the United States as the global growth pole shifts east.

;

;Yet the World Bank says hundreds of millions remain trapped in extreme poverty across Asia, with vast swathes of the continent also heavily exposed to the climate crisis, the lingering impact of the pandemic, as well as the risks of disruption to labour markets wrought by artificial intelligence.

;

;Philanthropy has the potential to plug some of the gaps.

;

;“We're seeing the biggest transfer of wealth in human history,” said Tristan Ace, chief programme officer for AVPN, which acts as a gateway to givers and social enterprises across Asia.

;

;“From India and Indonesia to China, extraordinary amounts of wealth have been created over the last 20 to 30 years,” Ace said. “下一代人希望做与祖父母不同的事情。 This presents a massive opportunity to think boldly and invest in solutions to future issues like the transition away from coal.”

;

;Sovereign funds, family offices, foundations, individual givers and social enterprises from across Asia attended the three-day conference called “Global Challenges: Asian Solutions”, to explore the potential of philanthropic giving to address the green transition, gender disparities, the youth skills gap, as well as equitable access to education and healthcare.

;

;But there is a long way to go, experts warn, with an extra US$1.5 trillion per year needed between now and 2030 for the Asia-Pacific to meet the United Nations' sustainable development goals, and a whopping US$23 trillion investment gap to meet climate goals in the region.

;

;“It is important that philanthropy moves beyond charity and becomes a key mechanism that supports social justice by addressing the root causes,” said Nancy Shukri, Malaysia's minister of women, family and community, delivering a speech on Thursday on behalf of Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.

;

;“An economy that truly serves humanity is one that embraces social justice, protects the environment and nurtures the well-being of the people. It is an economy that values people over profits.”

;

;Across Asia the ranks of the rich are getting deeper.

;

;This year's Hurun Rich List said China remained the biggest source of the super-rich with 969 billionaires, ahead of the US with 691 and India a distant third place. The 2022 HSBC study said 13.4 per cent of Singapore's population was projected to boast millionaire status by 2030, a higher percentage than anywhere in the Asia-Pacific.

;

;But as wealth has slowly leaned eastward since the 2008 financial crash, the chance to future-proof societies and economies is emerging.

;

;“Wealth has grown enormously in Asia, leading wealth holders to engage in social investing, apart from their philanthropy,” said Naina Subberwal Batra, CEO of AVPN.

;

;“Family offices are increasingly pushing their investment advisers to come up with a pipeline of investments that creates a net positive social impact. We aim to inspire and empower a new generation of givers,” she said.

;

;The vision for Asia is to create a culture where “giving is not just a choice, but a shared responsibility for the greater good”, she added.

;

;Giving is being driven by the young inheritors of business empires which have ridden the wave of surging growth. Many of these scions were educated overseas and have had a different window into the stark wealth gap, climate crisis and dug-in poverty of their own regions than their parents and grandparents, experts say.

;

;They have the potential to unleash a torrent of philanthropic cash across Asia, but critics of giving by the super-rich warn it can be a diversion from how the money was made as well as the unequal economic and political systems their influence underpins.

;

;“It's right that there's some scepticism,” AVPN's Ace said. “But these guys want to be part of the solution and already have an infrastructure that exists.”

;

;To drive real change, companies should weave giving into their “core business”, said Shahira Ahmed Bazari, managing director of Yayasan Hasanah.

;

;“In our post-globalised world, we face unprecedented challenges that demand innovative solutions and collective action,” she said.

;

;“Whether it is the far-reaching effects of climate change or economic disparity worsened by the pandemic, we hear the regular rallying cry to embed more sustainable practices in the way we do business as well as live our daily lives.”

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 20:20:03 +0800 China protests over Joe Biden’s ‘disparaging’ comments likening Xi Jinping to ‘dictator’https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3225052/china-protests-over-joe-bidens-disparaging-comments-likening-xi-jinping-dictator?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.22 20:01;
;;

;Beijing has officially protested to the White House against US President Joe Biden's remarks likening his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping to a “dictator”, with its mission in the US warning of “consequences” for provocations against China's political system and top leader.

;

;In a sign of renewed tensions days after US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's fence-mending trip to China, which included a meeting with Xi on Monday, Beijing has upped the ante against Washington, questioning its sincerity about stabilising their fraught ties.

;

;According to a statement issued on Thursday by the Chinese embassy in Washington, Beijing's top envoy to Washington Xie Feng “made serious representations and strong protests” to unnamed senior officials at the White House and State Department on Wednesday.

;

;The statement, citing an unnamed embassy spokesperson, said Biden's “disparaging” remarks were “erroneous, absurd and irresponsible, and form an open political provocation”.

;

;Blinken's China trip could put some US allies in 'precarious position'

;

;Foreign ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning also condemned Biden's comments as “extremely ridiculous and irresponsible” and said they “seriously violate basic facts, diplomatic protocol and China's political dignity”. However, her remarks, made during a regular briefing in Beijing on Wednesday, did not appear on the ministry's website.

;

;The embassy further elaborated Beijing's stance in its statement, saying “the smear of China's top leader” has undermined mutual trust and the “nature and impact are very negative”.

;

;“The Chinese government and people feel deeply affronted and firmly oppose it.拜登总统此前曾明确表示，美国尊重中国的制度，不寻求改变中国的制度，无意搞新冷战。 But with the latest irresponsible remarks about China's political system and top leader, people cannot help but question the sincerity of the US side,” it said.

;

;It vowed to “resolutely respond” to “political provocation against China's top leader”.

;

;“We urge the US side to immediately take earnest actions to undo the negative impact and honour its own commitments. Otherwise, it will have to bear all the consequences,” the embassy said in the statement.

;

;Biden's unusually pointed remarks about the Chinese leader came during a fundraiser in California on Tuesday as part of his campaign for next year's presidential election. He said Xi “got very upset” when the US shot down an alleged Chinese spy balloon in February – prompting Blinken to postpone his planned visit to China that month – because “he didn't know it was there”.

;

;“That's what's a great embarrassment for dictators, when they didn't know what happened,” he told donors, adding that Xi “wants to have a relationship again”.

;

;Asked Wednesday about Biden's comments, state department spokesman Vedant Patel said there was no need to walk them back.

;

;“The president believes that diplomacy, including this recent trip undertaken by the secretary, is a responsible way to manage tensions,” Patel said. “I don't think that the president's comments need to be clarified any further or to be interpreted any further.”

;

;The White House tried to play down Biden's remarks on Wednesday, saying it had “every expectation” of building on the progress Blinken made during his long-awaited trip to China earlier this week.

;

;“It should come as no surprise that the president speaks candidly about China and the differences that we have – we are certainly not alone in that,” said an unnamed senior administration official, according to a report by Agence France-Presse.

;

;“The president believes that diplomacy, including that undertaken by Secretary Blinken, is the responsible way to manage tensions,” the official added.

;

;During his two-day visit to Beijing, the first by America's top diplomat in five years, Blinken and Xi agreed on Monday to stabilise the rivalry between the countries so it did not veer into conflict. While the visit did not yield breakthroughs, both sides agreed to continue high-level diplomatic exchanges, including a visit by Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang to Washington.

;

;But tensions began to re-emerge just hours after Blinken wrapped up his Beijing trip on Monday, when Yang Tao, in charge of the Chinese foreign ministry's department of North American and Oceanian affairs, lashed out at Washington's “one-China” policy for Taiwan.

;

;Speaking at a media briefing late on Monday, Yang accused the US of back-pedalling on its previous commitments on Taiwan, which Beijing sees as a runaway province that must be reunited with the mainland, by force if necessary.

;

;Yang said the US initially recognised “there is only one China in the world and Taiwan is part of China”.但他随后又声称，多年来华盛顿决定将《与台湾关系法》和所谓的对台六项保证纳入其一个中国政策，这违背了北京和华盛顿双方的共识。 “China has resolutely opposed them and does not recognise them,” he added.

;

;'No fantasies' as China slams 'ridiculous' Biden comments on Xi: analysts

;

;During a meeting with Blinken on Monday, Xi's top foreign policy aide Wang Yi also put the blame squarely on the Biden administration for the deterioration of US-China ties, urging Washington to “reflect upon itself” about “US misperceptions towards China” and “misguided China policies”. However, Daniel Kritenbrink, US assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, hit back later saying a fruitful relationship could only be possible if it were a “two-way street”.

;

;Meanwhile, New Zealand Prime Minister Chris Hipkins, who is expected to visit Beijing and meet Xi next week, said on Thursday that he did not agree with Biden comparing the Chinese leader to “dictators”.

;

;The Group of Seven industrialised nations also expressed unity and support on Wednesday for closer coordination in dealing with China, after a meeting of G7 representatives with Blinken in London.

;Ukrainian missiles struck one of the few bridges linking the Crimea Peninsula with the Ukrainian mainland early on Thursday, cutting one of the main supply routes for Russian occupation forces in southern Ukraine as Kyiv pushes to drive them out.

;Vladimir Saldo, the head of the Russian-installed administration in occupied parts of Ukraine's Kherson province, released video on the Chonhar road bridge, where craters had been blasted through the asphalt.

;Alternative routes require hours-long detours over roads in poor condition. Russia's RIA new agency quoted Russian-installed transport officials in Crimea as saying repairing it could take weeks.

;

;“The psychological impact on the occupiers and the occupying power is even more important. There is no place on the territory of Kherson region where they can feel safe,” he said.

;

;Russian investigators said four missiles had been fired by Ukrainian forces at the bridge, the RIA news agency reported. It quoted a spokesman for military investigators as saying that markings found on the remains of one of the missiles suggested it had been made in France.

;Kyiv says it has recaptured eight villages so far, but it has yet to commit the bulk of its forces to the fight and its advancing troops have yet to reach the main Russian defensive lines.

;

;In its latest update on the fighting, Ukraine's military reported “partial success” in the southeast and east.

;

;Troops were reinforcing positions they reached after attacking towards the villages of Rivnopil and Staromayorske, said General Staff spokesman Andriy Kovaliov, referring to settlements in a Russian-held area where Ukrainian forces pushing south have so far captured four villages.

;

;He also described fierce fighting in the east, where Ukraine says it has been holding off Russian attacks.

;

;Russia says it has fended off the Ukrainian counter-attack and inflicted heavy casualties, which Ukraine denies.

;

;Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has acknowledged that progress has been slow so far, but says his troops are advancing cautiously into heavily mined and well-defended areas to minimise losses.

;

;Zelensky on Thursday accused Russia of planning a terrorist attack on the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, Europe's largest, which is in Russian-held territory near the front line. Moscow denied any such plan.
